It has approximately 700 lawyers across offices in [[Amsterdam]], [[Beijing]], [[Belfast]], [[Birmingham]], Bologna, [[Brussels]], [[Düsseldorf]], Frankfurt, [[Hamburg]], [[London]], Luxembourg, [[Manchester]], [[Milan]], [[Munich]], [[Palo Alto, California|Palo Alto]], [[Paris]], [[Rome]], [[Shanghai]], [[Turin]] and [[Venice]] and is the [[List of largest United Kingdom-based law firms|UK’s 29th-largest law firm measured by 2015/16 revenues]]. The firm has practices in sectors including Real Estate, Energy, Financial Services, Government & Public Services, Hotels & Leisure, Life Sciences, Media, Telecoms and Technology. The firm's origins can be traced back to the founding of the law firm Field Roscoe & Co. by [[Edwin Wilkins Field]] in 1835. ==History== ===Origins to 2000=== The origins of Fieldfisher can be traced back to the founding of the law firm Field Roscoe & Co. by [[Edwin Wilkins Field]] in 1835. In 1865 [[Theodore Waterhouse]] founded Waterhouse & Co. In 1897 Charles Fisher started his articles with Thomas Peacock, which later became TF Peacock Fisher. In 1930 Field Roscoe merged with Treherne Higgins. In 1969 Field Roscoe and TF Peacock Fisher merged to form Field Fisher & Co. In 1972 Field Fisher & Co. merged with Martineau and Reid to become Field Fisher Martineau. Field Fisher Waterhouse was created in 1989 by the merger of Field Fisher Martineau and Waterhouse & Co.{{cite news|url=http://www.legalweek.com/sites/legalweek/2009/12/13/field-fisher-waterhouse/|title=Field Fisher Waterhouse|accessdate=6 November 2016|publisher=Legal Week|date=13 December 2009}} Field Fisher Martineau was located at Lincoln’s Inn House in [[Holborn]], close to [[Red Lion Square]], a very convenient location for the law courts. Waterhouse & Co was originally located near [[St Paul's Cathedral]] and in 1971 had just nine partners; at the time all British law firms were fairly small they were not permitted to have more than twenty partners until 1968. The combined firm moved to new premises in [[Vine Street, London|Vine Street]] in June 1990. The oil company [[Royal Dutch Shell|Shell]] was a key client of Waterhouse & Co. and the firm worked on all of Shell’s major real estate deals, in particular its move to the [[Shell Centre]] in the 1950s. The firm’s relationship with Shell led to the development of a Japanese desk following a recommendation to Mitsubishi Bank by Shell. In 1998 Field Fisher Waterhouse merged with Allison & Humphreys (A&H).{{cite news|url=https://www.thelawyer.com/issues/17-november-1997/field-fisher-takes-over-allison-humphreys/|title=Field Fisher takes over Allison Humphreys|accessdate=6 November 2016|publisher=Legal Week|date=18 November 1997}} A&H was a media and communications specialist and complemented Field Fisher Waterhouse’s IT and internet expertise. The [[BBC]] was one of the key clients that A&H lawyers brought to the firm. ===2000 to present=== In June 2006 Field Fisher Waterhouse converted to LLP status. In 2007 the firm took its first steps into Europe; in April offices were established in Brussels and Hamburg,{{cite news|url=http://www.legalweek.com/sites/legalweek/2007/07/11/field-fisher-continues-euro-push-with-brussels-corporate-recruit/|title=Field Fisher continues Euro push with Brussels corporate business|accessdate=6 November 2016|publisher=Legal Week|date=26 February 2010}} and in November an office in Paris was opened.{{cite news|url=https://www.thelawyer.com/issues/29-october-2007/ffw-splits-ally-dubarry-to-open-in-paris-2/|title=FFW splits ally Dubarry to open in Paris|accessdate=6 November 2016|publisher=The Lawyer|date=31 October 2007}} The firm subsequently opened additional German offices in Munich and Düsseldorf.{{cite news|url=https://www.thelawyer.com/issues/online/ffw-snares-howrey-team-for-launches-in-munich-and-dusseldorf/|title=FFW snares Howrey team for launches in Munich and Dusseldorf|accessdate=6 November news|url=http://www.legalweek.com/sites/legalweek/2012/09/03/field-fisher-opens-us-base-in-palo-alto-in-stateside-client-push/?slreturn=20160923132647|title=Field Fisher opens US base in Palo Alto in renamed Field Fisher Ryser but continuing to operate as a financially separate partnership.{{cite {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2012}} {{main|Children in cocoa production}}
The '''Harkin–Engel Protocol''',{{Ref label|A|A|A}} sometimes referred to as the '''Cocoa Protocol''', is an international agreement aimed at ending the [[Worst Forms of Child Labour Convention#Predefined worst forms of child labour|worst forms of child labor]] (according to the [[International Labour Organization]]'s [[ILO Convention 182|Convention 182]]) and [[forced labor]] (according to ILO [[Forced Labour Convention|Convention 29]]) in the production of [[Theobroma cacao|cocoa]], the main ingredient in [[chocolate]]. The protocol was negotiated by [[United States Senate|U.S. Senator]] [[Tom Harkin]] and [[United States House of Representatives|U.S. Representative]] [[Eliot Engel]] in response to a documentary and multiple articles in 2000 and 2001 reporting widespread child [[slavery]] and [[Trafficking of children|child trafficking]] in the production of cocoa. The protocol was signed in September 2001. Joint Statements in 2001, 2005 and 2008 and a Joint Declaration in 2010 extended the commitment to address the problem. {{as of|2012}}, it is unclear if the protocol reduced [[children in cocoa production|child labor in the production of cocoa]], though the [[cocoa industry]] claims five of the six articles have been addressed and the final one is being actively pursued.
==Background== [[Image:Tom Harkin official portrait.jpg|thumb|120px|Sen. Tom Harkin]] [[Image:Eliot Engel, official photo portrait.jpg|thumb|120px|Rep. Eliot Engel]] In late 2000 a BBC documentary reported the use of enslaved children in the production of [[Theobroma cacao|cocoa]]—the main ingredient in [[chocolate]]<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.abc.net.au/local/audio/2012/04/12/3475859.htm |title= Cocoa shortage to push up chocolate price |author= Prue Bentley |publisher= ABC Ballarat |date= 12 April 2012 |accessdate=28 April 2012}}</ref>— in [[West Africa]].<ref name="combating">{{cite web |authorlink= International Labour Organization |title = Combating Child Labour in Cocoa Growing |publisher = [[International Labour Organization]] |year= 2005 |url= http://www.ilo.org/public//english//standards/ipec/themes/cocoa/download/2005_02_cl_cocoa.pdf |accessdate=26 April 2012}}</ref><ref>Wolfe and Shazzie, p. 98</ref> Other media followed by reporting widespread child [[slavery]] and [[Trafficking of children|child trafficking]] in the production of cocoa.<ref name="chocolate slavery">{{cite news |author= Humphrey Hawksley |authorlink = Humphrey Hawksley |title= Mali's children in chocolate slavery |publisher= BBC News |url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/africa/1272522.stm |date= 12 April 2001 |accessdate=2 January 2010}}</ref><ref name="accuses companies">{{cite news |author= Humphrey Hawksley |url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/1311982.stm |title= Ivory Coast accuses chocolate companies |publisher= BBC News |date= 4 May 2001 |accessdate=4 August 2010}}</ref><ref name="Raghavan1">{{cite web |author= Sudarsan Raghavan |author2= Sumana Chatterjee |last-author-amp= yes |title= Slaves feed world's taste for chocolate: Captives common in cocoa farms of Africa |newspaper = [[Milwaukee Journal Sentinel]] |date= 24 June 2001 |url= http://www2.jsonline.com/news/nat/jun01/slave24r062301.asp |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20060917014323/http://vision.ucsd.edu/~kbranson/stopchocolateslavery/atasteofslavery.html| archivedate = 17 September 2006 |accessdate=25 April 2012}}</ref> The cocoa industry was accused of profiting from child slavery and trafficking.<ref name="Payson2010 p26">Payson 2010, p. 26</ref> The European Cocoa Association dismissed these accusations as "false and excessive"<ref name="Payson2010 p26"/> and the industry said the reports were not representative of all areas.<ref name="BBC2000">{{cite news |url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/948876.stm |title= Cocoa farm slavery 'exaggerated' |publisher= [[BBC News]] |date= 29 September 2000 |accessdate=26 April 2012}}</ref> Later the industry acknowledged the working conditions for children were unsatisfactory and children's rights were sometimes violated<ref name="Payson2010 p26-7">Payson 2010, pp. 26–7</ref> and acknowledged the claims could not be ignored.<ref name="BBC2000"/>
In 2001, US Representative [[Eliot Engel]] introduced a legislative amendment to an agriculture bill. This amendment was to give the U.S. [[Food and Drug Administration]] (FDA) $250,000 to develop a label to indicate no child slave labor was used in growing or harvesting cocoa;<ref name="Salaam-Blyther">{{cite web |url= http://www.nationalaglawcenter.org/assets/crs/RL32990.pdf |author= Tiaji Salaam-Blyther |author2= Charles Hanrahan |author3= Nicolas Cook |last-author-amp= yes |title= Child Labor in West African Cocoa Production: Issues and U.S. Policy |publisher= [[Congressional Research Service]], [[The Library of Congress]] |date= 13 July 2005 |accessdate= 25 April 2012 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20120311140119/http://www.nationalaglawcenter.org/assets/crs/RL32990.pdf |archivedate= 11 March 2012 |df= dmy-all }}</ref> this label would be similar to the "[[dolphin safe]]" labels used for [[tuna]].<ref name="Tiger">{{cite news |url= http://www.salon.com/2003/02/14/chocolate/singleton/ |archive-url= https://archive.is/20130201222934/http://www.salon.com/2003/02/14/chocolate/singleton/ |dead-url= yes |archive-date= 1 February 2013 |title= Bittersweet chocolate |author= Caroline Tiger |publisher= Salon Media Group, Inc. |date= 14 February 2003 |accessdate= 19 April 2012 }}</ref> The amendment was approved in the [[US House of Representatives|House of Representatives]] vote of 291–115.<ref name="Payson2011 p13">Payson 2011, p. 13</ref>{{Ref label|B|B|B}} The bill appeared to have similar support in the [[US Senate|Senate]].<ref name="Payson2011 p13"/> The international cocoa industry strongly opposed it and the [[Chocolate Manufacturers Association]] hired former senators [[George J. Mitchell|George Mitchell]] and [[Bob Dole]] to [[lobbying|lobby]] against it.<ref name="Tiger"/> The cocoa industry faced potential consumer boycotts and harmful legislation if the bill were to pass.<ref name="Tiger"/> Mitchell and Dole encouraged the industry to make a deal,<ref name="Tiger"/> and before the bill went to a vote in the Senate, the cocoa industry agreed to address the problem without legislation.<ref name="Payson2011 p13"/>
Senator [[Tom Harkin]] and Engel negotiated a deal with the cocoa industry to create the Harkin–Engel Protocol.{{Ref label|A|A|A}}<ref name="Tiger"/> The protocol was signed in September 2001 with the objective to eliminate the "[[Worst Forms of Child Labour Convention#Predefined worst forms of child labour|worst forms of child labor]]" and adult forced labor on cocoa farms in West Africa.<ref name="HE Protocol">{{cite web |url= http://www.cocoainitiative.org/en/documents-manager/english/54-harkin-engel-protocol/file |title= Protocol for the growing and processing of cocoa beans and their derivative products in a manner that complies with ILO Convention 182 concerning the prohibition and immediate action for the elimination of the worst forms of child labor |publisher= [[International Cocoa Initiative]] |year= 2001 |accessdate= 25 April 2012 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20151208022828/http://www.cocoainitiative.org/en/documents-manager/english/54-harkin-engel-protocol/file |archivedate= 8 December 2015 |df= dmy-all }}</ref> It was signed and witnessed by the heads of eight major chocolate companies, Harkin, Engel, Senator [[Herb Kohl]], the ambassador of Côte d'Ivoire, the director of the [[International Programme on the Elimination of Child Labor]], and others.<ref name="HE Protocol"/>
==Protocol and 2001 Joint Statement== The Harkin–Engel Protocol is a voluntary public-private agreement to eliminate the [[Worst Forms of Child Labour Convention#Predefined worst forms of child labour|worst forms of child labor]] (defined according to the [[International Labour Organization]] (ILO)'s [[ILO Convention 182|Convention 182]]) in the growth and processing of cocoa in [[Côte d’Ivoire]] and [[Ghana]].<ref name="Payson2011 p7">Payson 2011, p. 7</ref> The protocol was a voluntary agreement that partnered governments, the global cocoa industry, cocoa producers, cocoa laborers, non-governmenal organizations.<ref name="HE Protocol"/> The agreement laid out a series of date-specific actions, including the development of voluntary standards of public certification.<ref name="HE Protocol"/> The Protocol did not commit the industry to ending all child labor in cocoa production, only the worst forms of it. The parties agreed to a six-article plan: # Public statement of the need for and terms of an action plan—The cocoa industry acknowledged the problem of forced child labor and will commit "significant resources" to address the problem. # Formation of multi-sectoral advisory groups—By 1 October 2001, an advisory group will be formed to research labor practices. By 1 December 2001, industry will form an advisory group and formulate appropriate remedies to address the worst forms of child labor. # Signed joint statement on child labor to be witnessed at the ILO—By 1 December 2001, a statement must be made recognizing the need to end the worst forms of child labor and identify developmental alternatives for the children removed from labor. # Memorandum of cooperation—By 1 May 2002, Establish a joint action program of research, information exchange, and action to enforce standards to eliminate the worst forms of child labor. Establish a monitor and compliance with the standards. # Establish a joint foundation—By 1 July 2002, industry will form a foundation to oversee efforts to eliminate the worst forms of child labor. It will perform field projects and be a clearinghouse on best practices. # Building toward credible standards—By 1 July 2005, the industry will develop and implement industry-wide standards of public certification that cocoa has been grown without any of the worst forms of child labor.<ref name="HE Protocol"/>
A 2001 Joint Statement extended the protocol to also identify and eliminate forced labor (defined according to ILO [[Forced Labour Convention|Convention 29]]) in the production of cocoa.<ref name="Payson2011 p100">Payson 2011, pp. 100–2</ref>
The protocol laid out a [[non-binding]] agreement for the cocoa industry to regulate itself without any legal implications,<ref name="Payson2011 p13"/> but Engel threatened to reintroduce legislation if the deadlines were not met.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://engel.house.gov/index.cfm?sectionid=68&sectiontree=6,64,68&itemid=329 |title= For Valentines Day; Engel and Harkin warn Americans that holiday chocolate is made by child slaves |publisher= Eliot Engel House website |date= 14 February 2005 |accessdate=27 April 2012}}</ref> This agreement was the one of the first times an American industry was subjected to [[Industry self-regulation|self-regulation]] and one of the first times self-regulation was used to address an international [[human rights]] issue.<ref name="Payson2011 p13"/>
==2005 progress and Joint Statement== By July 2005—the deadline date—the cocoa industry made progress on their goal to eliminate the worst forms of child labor. Most of the requirements were achieved by the deadline.<ref name="Payson2007 p21">Payson 2007, p. 21</ref> Before the protocol was signed, the cocoa industry acknowledged the problem of forced child labor to address part of Article 1.<ref name="HE Protocol"/> A Joint Statement was made in 2001 to address part of Article 3.<ref name="Payson2011 p100">Payson 2011, pp. 100–2</ref> The '''[[International Cocoa Initiative]]''' (ICI) was established in 2002 to address part of Article 5.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.cocoainitiative.org/images/stories/pdf/ICI_Leaflets_presentations/ICI_Information_Kit_-_April_2012_-_About_the_ICI_Foundation.pdf |title= About the ICI Foundation |publisher= International Cocoa Initiative |accessdate= 27 April 2012 }}{{Dead link|date=October 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Through the ICI, $3 million was spent on pilot projects.<ref name="Payson2007 p105">Payson 2007, pp. 105–16</ref> The [[International Institute of Tropical Agriculture]] (IITA) was assigned to survey West Africans about children in cocoa production.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.dol.gov/ilab/media/reports/iclp/cocoafindings.pdf |title= Summary of Findings from the Child Labor Surveys In the Cocoa Sector of West Africa: Cameroon, Côte d’Ivoire, Ghana, and Nigeria |publisher= International Institute of Tropical Agriculture |date= July 2002 |accessdate= 27 April 2012 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20111024135108/http://www.dol.gov/ilab/media/reports/iclp/cocoafindings.pdf |archivedate= 24 October 2011 |df= dmy-all }}</ref> Pilot projects were formed to monitor child labor.<ref name="Joint2005">Payson 2011, pp. 107–9</ref> In 2004, the cocoa industry created and funded Verification Working Group. The funding was discontinued in 2006, but another company was contracted to perform verification in 2007.<ref name="Payson2007 p9">Payson 2007, p. 9</ref>
But all the protocol requirements were not met by the deadline.<ref name="Payson2007 p21"/> The cocoa industry failed to create and implement an industry-wide certification standard to indicate that cocoa had not been produced with the worst forms of child labor.<ref name="Payson2007 p21"/> The chocolate companies were criticized for executing the protocol at the smallest cost,<ref name="Tiger"/> remaining mostly hands-off in the process without changing the process,<ref name="ILRF 2005">{{cite web |url= http://www.laborrights.org/projects/childlab/cocoa_childlabor_update_May05.pdf |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20051226133450/http://www.laborrights.org/projects/childlab/cocoa_childlabor_update_May05.pdf |title= May 2005 Report: Child Labor in Agriculture |publisher= International Labor Rights Fund |date= May 2005 |archivedate= 26 December 2005 |accessdate=28 April 2012 }}</ref> and maintaining a business model dependent on child labor.<ref name="ILRF 2005"/> More importantly, they did not alter the price of chocolate to enable the cocoa producers to end the practice of slavery.<ref name="Tiger"/><ref name="ILRF 2005"/> One of the major obstacles to executing the protocol was the [[First Ivorian Civil War|Ivorian Civil War]].<ref name="Tiger"/><ref name="Parenti">{{cite news |url= http://money.cnn.com/2008/01/24/news/international/chocolate_bittersweet.fortune/ |title= Chocolate's bittersweet economy |author= Christian Parenti |work= Fortune |date= 15 February 2008 |accessdate=28 April 2012}}</ref> Along with [[diamond]]s and [[timber]], cocoa was a [[conflict resource]] that made money for the militants.<ref name="Parenti"/>
By July 2005 the extent of child involvement in cocoa production was unclear. It was also unclear if the cocoa industry's efforts were helping the problem.<ref name="Payson2007 p13">Payson 2007, p. 13</ref> On 1 July 2005, all the parties agreed to an extension of the protocol through a Joint Statement.<ref name="Payson2010 p28">Payson 2010, p. 28</ref> The 2005 Joint Statement gave the cocoa industry three more years to implement the protocol. The Joint Statement stated industry would form a certification system for half of the growing regions in Côte d'Ivoire and Ghana. The Joint Statement also stated industry would support programs for the local cocoa-growing communities including teacher training programs.<ref name="Joint2005"/>
The [[US Congress]] was not satisfied with the cocoa industry's response. It gave responsibility to the [[US Department of Labor]] to find a university contractor to oversee the efforts to eliminate the worst forms of child labor.<ref name="Payson2011 p13"/> In 2006, a $4.3 million contract was awarded to the [[Payson Center for International Development]] at [[Tulane University]] through 2009.<ref name="Parenti"/><ref name="Payson2011 p13-4">Payson 2011, pp. 13–4</ref> In 2006, the Payson Center reported progress had been made, but children were still working in cocoa production, including performing dangerous tasks, and regularly miss school.<ref name="Parenti"/> The cocoa industry was criticized for a lack of certification standards and the governments of Côte d'Ivoire and Ghana were criticized for a lack of transparency.<ref name="Parenti"/> In 2006, the president of the [[World Cocoa Foundation]] said, "While progress has been made and we have learned valuable lessons, much more is required."<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.worldcocoafoundation.org/who-we-are/general-press-releases/wcf_industryupdate.asp |title= Chocolate Industry Expands Sustainable Cocoa Farming Efforts |publisher= World Cocoa Foundation |date= 3 February 2006 |accessdate= 27 April 2012 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20120615125035/http://www.worldcocoafoundation.org/who-we-are/general-press-releases/wcf_industryupdate.asp |archivedate= 15 June 2012 |df= dmy-all }}</ref>
After the deadline passed, the [[International Labor Rights Fund]] filed a lawsuit in 2005 under the [[Alien Tort Claims Act]] against [[Nestle]], [[Cargill]] and [[Archer Daniels Midland]] on behalf of three Malian children. The suit alleged the children were trafficked to Côte d'Ivoire, forced into slavery, and experienced frequent beatings on a cocoa plantation.<ref name="Dworkin">{{cite news |url= http://www.chron.com/opinion/outlook/article/Delicious-idea-End-child-slavery-by-eating-1837193.php |title= Delicious idea: End child slavery by eating chocolate |author= Tex Dworkin |newspaper= Houston Chronicle |date= 12 February 2007 |accessdate=30 April 2012}}</ref><ref name="IRLF suit">{{cite web |url= http://www.laborrights.org/stop-child-labor/cocoa-campaign/news/10993 |title= On Halloween, Nestlé Claims no {{sic|Respons|iblity|nolink=y}} for Child Labor |publisher= [[International Labor Rights Forum]] |date= 30 October 2006 |accessdate=30 April 2012}}</ref> In September 2010, the [[United States District Court for the Central District of California|US District Court for the Central District of California]] determined corporations cannot be held liable for violations of international law and dismissed the suit. The case was appealed to the [[US Court of Appeals]].<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.earthrights.org/publication/amicus-brief-doe-v-nestle |title= Amicus Brief in Doe v. Nestle |publisher= [[EarthRights International]] |accessdate=30 April 2012}}</ref><ref name="Jarmillo">{{cite web |url= http://www.csrandthelaw.com/2010/09/articles/litigation/alien-tort-statute/second-circuit-holds-that-corporations-are-not-proper-defendants-under-the-alien-tort-statute/ |title= Second Circuit Holds that Corporations are not Proper Defendants under the Alien Tort Statute |author= Gwendolyn Wilber Jaramillo |publisher= [[Foley and Hoag LLP]]|work=[[Corporate Social Responsibility and the Law]] |date= 19 September 2010 |accessdate=30 April 2012}}</ref>
==2008 progress and Joint Statement== By the revised deadline—1 June 2008—all the objectives were still not met. Some progress had been made; for example, the cocoa industry had provided $10 million to the ICI. In 2006–07 the ICI had 17 training sessions in Côte d'Ivoire and 23 in Ghana to sensitize the governmental officials, police and media about child and adult labor practices. The focus of the Joint Statement was that of certification. The cocoa industry performed data collection had on 50% of the growing areas in both Côte d'Ivoire and Ghana. But independent verification, partially funded by industry, on those areas was not fully completed. The deadline was extended until the end of 2010. At that time, industry was required to have a full certification and independent verification.<ref name="Payson2011 p111-4">Payson 2011, pp. 111–4</ref>
All parties reaffirmed their commitment to eliminate the worst forms of child labor. The cocoa industry committed to work with the governments of Côte d'Ivoire and Ghana to set up independent certification by the end of 2010; assist the governments to target remediation efforts based on the independent certification; and support the ICI as it expands to more local communities and provide training on safe labor practices.<ref name="Payson2011 p111-4"/>
In 2009, cocoa from Côte d'Ivoire and [[Nigeria]] was added to a list of products made by forced child labor maintained by the Department of Labor.<ref name="Payson2010 p29">Payson 2010, p. 29</ref> This listing stemmed from a request by [[Anti-Slavery International]] in 2004 to investigate if Ivorian cocoa should be on this list.<ref>{{cite journal |url= http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/FR-2004-05-10/pdf/E4-1047.pdf |title= Notice and Request for Information Regarding Forced/Indentured Child Labor Pursuant to Executive Order 13126 |publisher= US Federal Register |volume= 69 |issue=90 |date= 10 May 2004 |pages= 25923–5 |accessdate=28 April 2012}}</ref> [[Executive Order 13126]] requires federal contractors who supply products on the list must prove they have made a good faith effort to determine if the products were produced under forced labor.<ref name="EO 13126">{{cite web |url= http://www.dol.gov/ILAB/regs/eo13126/main.htm |title= Executive Order 13126 |author= Bureau of International Labor Affairs |publisher= US Department of Labor |date= 3 April 2012 |accessdate=28 April 2012}}</ref> Thus contractors must prove they have made a good faith effort to determine if cocoa was produced under forced labor.<ref name="EO 13126"/> Côte d'Ivoire<ref name="US State TIP IC">{{cite web |url= https://www.state.gov/documents/organization/123361.pdf |title= Trafficking in Persons Report |publisher = US State Department |pages= 113–5 |date= June 2009 |accessdate=23 April 2012}}</ref> and Ghana<ref name="US State TIP Gh">{{cite web |url= https://www.state.gov/documents/organization/123362.pdf |title= Trafficking in Persons Report |publisher = US State Department |pages= 142–4 |date= June 2009 |accessdate=23 April 2012}}</ref> were placed on the 2009 [[US State Department]]'s [[Office to Monitor and Combat Trafficking in Persons#Activities|Tier 2 Watch List]] for human trafficking due in part to the trafficking of children in cocoa production.
In 2009 the Department of Labor awarded a second, $1.2 million contract to the Payson Center to continue the oversight through 2011.<ref name="Payson2011 p13-4"/>
==2010 Joint Declaration and Framework of Action== The 2010 Joint Declaration summarized the pledge of the Harkin–Engel Protocol and reaffirmed the commitment to achieve the objectives of the protocol. The purpose of the framework of action was to reduce the worst forms of child labor 70% by 2020. Specifically, they were to remove children from and prevent children's involvement in the worst forms of child labor, promote sustainable livelihoods for cocoa growers, establish and implement community-based child labor monitoring systems, and continue national child labor surveys. The Joint Declaration established the Child Labor Cocoa Coordinating Group to coordinate the activities of the framework and provide governance.<ref name="Payson2011 p116-25">Payson 2011, pp. 116–25</ref>
To achieve the goals, the governments of Côte d'Ivoire and Ghana must fund and conduct child labor surveys, provide remediation for children removed from the worst forms of child labor, prevent children from becoming involved in the worst forms of child labor, enforce laws to protect the children from the worst forms of child labor, and develop the infrastructure of the cocoa growing regions. The responsibility of the cocoa and chocolate industries is to continue to support the child labor surveys, support remediation efforts, provide sustainable livelihoods for the households of cocoa growers, try to ensure cocoa supply chains are using safe practices. The industries will commit $7 million over the next five years with the possibility of $3 million more for remediation activities. The responsibility of the US Department of Labor is to commit $10 million in 2010 for a multi-year program to support the framework and report on the progress of these efforts.<ref name="Payson2011 p116-25"/>
==2011 status update== Household surveys and governmental research in Côte d'Ivoire and Ghana showed that there were 1.8 million children working in cocoa agriculture. About 5% in Côte d'Ivoire and 10% in Ghana worked for pay. Children are commonly involved in hazardous work and some are still involved in the worst forms of child labor.<ref name="Payson2011 p7">Payson 2011, p. 7</ref>
Between 2001 and 2009, several thousand children were involved in remediation activities including in each country. These activities include withdrawal, rehabilitation, reinsertion, education and vocational training and these efforts were attributed to funding related to the Harkin–Engel Protocol.<ref name="Payson2011 p8">Payson 2011, p. 8</ref> Less than 5% of all children were exposed to activities related to the protocol.<ref name="Payson2011 p7"/>
In 2011, the Payson Center reported the cocoa industry has not fully completed any of the six articles. Industry had not completed the 2005 Joint Statement commitment of certification for 50% of the growing areas in the two countries, much less the 2008 Joint Statement commitment of remediation activities in 100% of the growing areas. Côte d'Ivoire had only achieved remediation in 3.8% and Ghana in 31% of the growing areas.<ref name="Payson2011 p9">Payson 2011, p. 9</ref>
The cocoa industry still has to prove it can self-regulate. The Payson Center recommended the industry create a certification system that can assure consumers the worst forms of child labor are not used in production, create an independent verification of that certification system, implement child labor monitoring systems, and increase remediation activities to address the worst forms of child labor.<ref name="Payson2011 p10-2">Payson 2011, pp. 10–2</ref>
==Criticism== In 2001, the Child Labor Coalition, a collection of advocacy groups focusing on child labor issues in the US and worldwide, criticized the protocol for only addressing Côte d'Ivoire and Ghana. It suggested extending the protocol to the whole world, because exploitative practices were also reported in the cocoa industries in [[Brazil]] and [[Indonesia]]. The Child Labor Coalition also recommended that the chocolate industry set the price of chocolate so that the producers make enough money to fairly compensate their workers.<ref name="Tiger"/>
In 2011, ten years after implementation, it was unclear if the protocol had any effect in reducing child labor. One Payson Center researcher claimed few of the protocol commitments have been implemented, but the ICI claimed five of the six articles have been completed and they are actively working on the sixth.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://thecnnfreedomproject.blogs.cnn.com/2011/09/19/the-human-cost-of-chocolate/ |title= The Human Cost of Chocolate |author= Tricia Escobedo |publisher= [[CNN]] |date= 19 September 2011 |accessdate=28 April 2012}}</ref>
In 2012, {{ill|Miki Mistrati|da}}, creator of the award-winning documentary, ''[[The Dark Side of Chocolate]]'', claimed the protocol is just “a document and politics” because there has been no progress. He thinks that the same issues will be present in five years and that changes will not come through the protocol, but instead from consumers who demand change.<ref>{{Cite web|title = The bitter truth - Khaleej Times|url = http://www.khaleejtimes.com/article/20120224/ARTICLE/302249998/1002|website =[[Khaleej Times]]|date= February 24, 2012|accessdate = January 15, 2017}}</ref>
==Notes== {{Note label|A|A|A}}The protocol is formally called "Protocol for the Growing and Processing of Cocoa Beans and Their Derivative Products In a Manner that Complies with ILO Convention 182 Concerning the Prohibition and Immediate Action for the Elimination of the Worst Forms of Child Labor."<ref name="HE Protocol"/> <br/> {{Note label|B|B|B}}It has also been reported that this vote was 107–76,<ref name="Salaam-Blyther"/><ref name="Payson2010 p27">Payson 2010, p. 27</ref> but the final Payson report has the result as 291–115.<ref name="Payson2011 p13"/>

{{Orphan|date=November 2014}} '''Jacobo Ríos Rodríguez''' is ''Maître de Conférences'' in [[International Public Law]] and Vice-Dean of the Faculty of Law of [[University of Perpignan Via Domitia]] (Associate Professor/Senior Lecturer, French civil servant),<ref>{{cite web|title="Maîtres de Conférences", Ministère de l'enseignement supérieur et de la recherche|url=http://www.enseignementsup-recherche.gouv.fr/cid22657/maitres-de-conferences.html}}</ref> where he is also Coordinator of International Programs.
His research topics focus on the role of the individual on the international legal order, especially on themes such as migration (trafficking and smuggling),<ref>{{cite web|title=Le trafic illicite de migrants par voie maritime|url=http://www.pedone.info/sfdi/Nancy/21-Rios-Rodriguez.pdf}}</ref> human rights, international organizations experts,<ref>{{cite web|title=L'expert en droit international, éds. Pedone (Paris)|url=http://www.pedone.info/expert/expert.html}}</ref> UN governance, cinematic representation of law, universal jurisdiction in the prosecution of international crimes, and environmental law. With regard to the field of international migration, he has participated in the Centre for Studies and Research in International Law and International Relations, [[The Hague Academy of International Law]], 2010.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Hague Academy of International Law, Centre for Studies and Research in International Law and International Relations|url=https://www.hagueacademy.nl/centre-for-studies-and-research-in-international-law-and-international-relations/}}</ref> His publications have appeared in three different languages, edited by French publishers (Dalloz, La Documentation française, Pedone, Société de législation comparée ...), English publishers (Hart Publishing - Oxford), Spanish publishers (Tirant lo Blanch) and Belgian publishers (Bruylant). He has also published articles on international law in several newspapers.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Argentina y Malvinas|journal=El Pais|url=http://elpais.com/elpais/2013/03/20/opinion/1363805276_330708.html}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|title=Siria y el Derecho Internacional|journal=La Voz de Galicia|url=http://www.lavozdegalicia.es/SSEE/print.jsp?idContenido=0003_201309G14P16992&idSeccion=B67FBB760A80B198004568F8C381B8F1}}</ref>
He holds a PhD in Law from the Universities of Paris I Panthéon-Sorbonne (France) and La Coruña (Spain),<ref>{{cite web|title=Thèse de doctorat, L'expert en droit international|url=http://www.theses.fr/2008PA010317|website=Thèses.fr}}</ref> a master's degree in International Law and International Organizations from the University of Paris I Panthéon-Sorbonne and an ''Habilitation à diriger des recherches - HDR'' from the University of Perpignan Via Domitia<ref>{{cite journal|title=REEI, Recension "L'expert en droit international"|url=http://dialnet.unirioja.es/descarga/articulo/3427445.pdf}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=HDR "Le droit international à l'épreuve de la gouvernance"|url=http://www.univ-perp.fr/medias/fichier/hdr-rios-rodriguez-17-06-13_1405692407472-doc?INLINE=FALSE}}</ref> (highest university degree in France)<ref>{{cite journal|title=Legifrance, Habilitation à diriger des recherches|url=http://www.legifrance.gouv.fr/jopdf/common/jo_pdf.jsp?numJO=0&dateJO=19881129&numTexte=&pageDebut=14825&pageFin=}}</ref> which entitles him to supervise PhD theses.
Dr. Ríos has two nationalities, Spanish and French. He has published two monographs<ref>{{cite web|title=Le droit public à l'épreuve de la gouvernance, éds. PUP|url=http://www.lgdj.fr/colloques-etudes-rapports/233808347/droit-public-epreuve-gouvernance-journee-franco-espagnole}}</ref> and about thirty articles. He has also edited two collective works, organized several symposiums<ref>{{cite web|title=Le cinéma, miroir du droit et de la politique|url=http://www.asso-afda.fr/IMG/pdf/20130409_12_le_cinema_miroir_du_droit_et_de_la_politique.pdf}}</ref> and participated in a wide range of symposiums and conferences. Moreover, Dr. Ríos is a member of the ''Société française pour le droit international'' (SFDI) and of the ''Asociación española de profesores de Derecho Internacional y Relaciones Internacionales'' (AEPDIRI), and he has also collaborated as an expert with the ''Agence nationale de la recherche'' (ANR)<ref>{{cite web|title=Agence nationale de la recherche (ANR), website|url=http://www.agence-nationale-recherche.fr/}}</ref> in France.

[[Criminal law]]
[[Tort law]] | notable_ideas = | influences = [[H. L. A. Hart]]
[[Tony Honoré]]
[[Joseph Raz]] | influenced = | website = }} '''John Gardner''' [[Fellow of the British Academy|FBA]] (born 23 March 1965) is a Scottish [[Legal philosopher|legal philosopher]]. He is senior research fellow at [[All Souls College]], [[Oxford University]], and was previously the [[Professor of Jurisprudence (University of Oxford)|Professor of Jurisprudence]] at the University of Oxford and fellow of [[University College, Oxford]].{{Cite web|title = John Gardner|url = https://www.law.ox.ac.uk/people/john-gardner|website = Oxford Law Faculty|accessdate = 2015-12-28}}{{Cite web|title = John Gardner at Home|url = http://users.ox.ac.uk/~lawf0081/biograph2.htm|website = users.ox.ac.uk|accessdate = 2015-12-28}} == Life and career == Gardner attended [[Glasgow Academy]] from 1970 to 1982. The following year he moved to the University of Oxford, where he received his [[Bachelor of Arts|BA]], [[Bachelor of Civil Law|BCL]] (winning the [[Vinerian Scholarship]]), [[Master of Arts|MA]], and [[DPhil]], under the supervision of [[Joseph Raz]] and [[Tony Honoré]]. He has been associated with [[New College, Oxford|New College]] (as a student, 1983–7), [[All Souls College, Oxford|All Souls College]] (as a fellow, 1986–91 and 1998–2000), and [[Brasenose College, Oxford|Brasenose College]] (as a fellow, 1991–1996). From 1996 to 2000 he was reader in legal philosophy at [[King's College London]]. In 2000, at the age of just 35, he was appointed [[Professor of Jurisprudence (University of Oxford)|professor of jurisprudence]], taking over the chair previously held by [[H. L. A. Hart]] and [[Ronald Dworkin]]. In summer 2016 he took up a senior research fellowship at All Souls.{{Cite web|url = http://leiterreports.typepad.com/blog/2016/02/oxfords-professor-of-jurisprudence-john-gardner-to-take-up-senior-research-fellowship-at-all-souls-c.html|title = Leiter Reports: A Philosophy Blog: Oxford's Professor of Jurisprudence, John Gardner, to take up Senior Research Fellowship at All Souls College|website = leiterreports.typepad.com|access-date = 2016-03-10}} Gardner has held several visiting positions, including at [[Columbia Law School|Columbia]] (2000), [[Yale Law School|Yale]] (2002–3, 2005), [[Princeton University|Princeton]] (2008), the [[Australian National University]] (2003, 2006, 2008), and most recently [[Cornell University|Cornell]] (2015). A barrister since 1988, Gardner was elected a Bencher of the Honourable Society of the [[Inner Temple]] (one of the [[Inns of Court]]) in 2002. He was elected a fellow of the [[British Academy]] in 2013.http://www.britac.ac.uk/users/professor-john-gardner ==Philosophical work== Gardner writes on general [[jurisprudence]], the philosophical foundations of [[tort law]] and [[criminal law]], and [[moral philosophy]]. He describes [[Tony Honoré]], his colleague since 1986, as his mentor;{{Cite journal|url = |title = Tony Honoré as Teacher and Mentor: a Personal Memoir|last = Gardner|first = John|date = 2008|journal = Aspects of Law in Late Antiquity|doi = |pmid = |access-date = |editor-last = |publisher = privately published}} and says he owes his approach to general jurisprudence to [[H. L. A. Hart]].{{Cite book|title = Law as a Leap of Faith|last = Gardner|first = John|publisher = OUP|year = 2012|isbn = |location = Oxford|pages = }} His work is often compared to that of Joseph Raz. Gardner is also influenced by [[Aristotle]] and by [[Bernard Williams]], one of his DPhil examiners.{{Cite web|title = Law as a leap of faith: John Gardner interviewed by Richard Marshall|url = http://www.3ammagazine.com/3am/law-as-a-leap-of-faith/|website = 3:AM Magazine|accessdate = 2015-12-28|language = en-US}} == Publications == * ''Offences and Defences: Selected Essays in the Philosophy of Criminal Law'' (2007) * ''Law as a Leap of Faith: Essays on Law in General'' (2012) * ''From Personal Life to Private Law'' (forthcoming) ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://users.ox.ac.uk/~lawf0081/ Personal home page] *[https://www.law.ox.ac.uk/people/john-gardner University of Oxford profile] *[http://www.3ammagazine.com/3am/law-as-a-leap-of-faith/ Law as a Leap of Faith: John Gardner interviewed by Richard Marshall] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Gardner, John}} [[Category:1964 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People educated at the Glasgow Academy]] [[Category:Professors of Jurisprudence (University of Oxford)]] [[Category:Scottish legal scholars]] [[Category:Alumni of New College, Oxford]] [[Category:Fellows of University College, Oxford]] [[Category:Academics of King's College London]] [[Category:Philosophers of law]] [[Category:People from Glasgow]] [[Category:Fellows of All Souls College, Oxford]] [[Category:Fellows of Brasenose College, Oxford]] [[Category:Members of the Inner Temple]] [[Category:Fellows of the British Academy]] [[Category:Scottish philosophers]] {{Scotland-law-bio-stub}} {{Scotland-academic-bio-stub}}

Bocock]] |successor5 = [[Thomas Russell Bowden]] | birth_date = December 24, 1823 | birth_place = [[Winchester, Virginia]] | resting_place = Winchester, Virginia | death_date = {{death date and age|1897|2|13|1823|12|24}} | death_place = [[Lexington, Virginia]] | party = [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] | religion = | spouse = Laura Holmes Powell Tucker | children = [[Henry St. George Tucker III|Henry St. George Tucker]] others | website = | footnotes = |profession = [[lawyer]], [[professor]] }} '''John Randolph Tucker''' (December 24, 1823 – February 13, 1897) was an American lawyer, author, and politician from [[Virginia]]. From a distinguished slaveholding family, he was elected Virginia's attorney general in 1857 and after re-election served during the [[American Civil War]] ([[James S. Wheat]] served as attorney general in Union-held portions of the state). After a pardon and [[Congressional Reconstruction]], Tucker was elected as U.S. Congressman (1875-1887), and later served as the first dean of the [[Washington and Lee University Law School]].https://law.wlu.edu/about-wandl-law/leadership/aba-presidents Biography at Washington & Lee Law SchoolCongBio|T000401 ==Early life and family== Tucker was born in [[Winchester, Virginia]] on Christmas eve in 1823, the son of Anna Evalina Hunter Tucker (1789-1855) and her husband Judge [[Henry St. George Tucker, Sr.|Henry St. George Tucker]] (1780-1848). A grandson of [[St. George Tucker]], J.R. Tucker would become proud of his heritage among the [[First Families of Virginia]]. His father and many relatives owned plantations and enslaved persons. Nonetheless, several of his siblings never reached adulthood. His brothers Dr. Alfred Bland Tucker (1830-1862) and Lt.Col. St. George Hunter Tucker (1828-1863) would die of consumption while in the [[Confederate States Army]]; his brother Dr. [[David Hunter Tucker]] (1815-1871) became a professor at three medical schools including the [[Medical College of Virginia]] and survived his Confederate service. His brother [[Nathaniel Beverley Tucker (journalist)|Nathaniel Beverley Tucker]] (1820-1890) would become a Confederate diplomat and later a journalist. John Randolph Tucker attended a private school near his Winchester home, then entered the [[Richmond Academy]]. He finished his studies at the [[University of Virginia]], graduating with a legal degree in 1844. He married Laura Powell in 1848. They had one son who survived to adulthood, [[Henry St. George Tucker, III]] (who later became a U.S. Congressman). Their daughters who married well and survived their parents included: Anne Holmes Tucker McGuire (1850 - 1914), Gertrude Tucker Logan (1856 - 1925), and Laura Randolph Tucker Pendleton (1860 - 1946). ==Early legal and political career== John Randolph Tucker was admitted to the Virginia bar in 1845, and began a private legal practice in [[Winchester, Virginia|Winchester]]. In 1854 he delivered a major speech to the literary societies at [[College of William and Mary]] which argued that slavery was consistent with republicanism. He also became active in politics and was a presidential elector on the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] ticket in 1852 and 1856. ==American Civil War== Voters elected Tucker [[State Attorney General|Attorney General]] of the [[Commonwealth of Virginia]] in 1857, and he served during the [[American Civil War]], until the Commonwealth surrendered to Union forces in 1865. His siblings also actively supported the [[Confederate States of America|Confederate]] cause, two as Confederate doctors, Nathaniel Beverley Tucker as a Confederate diplomat, and his lawyer brother St. George Hunter Tucker recruited the Ashland Grays (part of the [[15th Virginia Infantry]]) and served at Lt. Col., winning plaudits for his conduct at the [[Battle of Malvern Hill]] before resigning his commission and dying of consumption in Charlottesville in 1863. ==Postwar legal and political career== J. Randolph Tucker received a pardon and resumed his private legal practice. Elected to the [[United States House of Representatives]] as a Democrat in 1875, he served until 1887. He was chairman of the [[United States House Committee on Ways and Means|House Committee on Ways and Means]] in the [[46th United States Congress|46th Congress]] and chairman of the [[United States House Committee on the Judiciary|House Committee on the Judiciary]] in the [[48th United States Congress|48th]] and [[49th United States Congress|49th]] Congresses. He took an active part in the debates on the [[tariff]], in opposition to the protective policy. His speeches on other questions include those on the [[Electoral Commission (United States)|Electoral Commission]] bill, the constitutional doctrine as to the presidential count, the Hawaiian treaty in 1876, the use of the army at the polls, in 1879, and Chinese emigration, in 1883. He introduced legislation broadening the power of the federal [[Court of Claims (United States)|Court of Claims]] to hear Constitutional claims in 1886, which became known as the [[Tucker Act]]. He declined to be renominated to the House in 1886. He was co-sponsor of the 1887 [[Edmunds–Tucker Act]]. Tucker was an exemplar of the racist views of his day. Speaking on the House floor, he asserted that “We did not ordain and establish this Constitution for the Chinaman and for all the other races of the earth. . . . I hold that this Constitution was ordained and established by our fathers for their posterity of the Caucasian people of America.”13 Cong. Rec. Appendix 56 Not surprisingly, he was also not supportive of the post-Civil War push to grant rights to African Americans, declaring that “. . . there is not a philosophical statesman in this land who to-day does not say either that the citizenship and the voting power of the African race in the South is a failure--either that or that it is an unsolved problem of our future. We have that one disease in the body-politic, which God grant we may recover from.”13 Cong. Rec. 57 ===Electoral History=== *'''1874'''; Tucker was elected to the U.S. House of Representatives with 65.23% of the vote, defeating Republican [[J. Foote Johnson]]. *'''1876'''; Tucker was re-elected with 59.61% of the vote, defeating Republican [[George H. Burch]]. *'''1878'''; Tucker was re-elected with 63.42% of the vote, defeating Independent Democrat [[Camm Patterson]] and Independent [[Lewis W. Cabell]]. *'''1880'''; Tucker was re-elected with 59.56% of the vote, defeating Readjuster [[James A. Frazier]] and Republican [[David J. Woodfin]]. *'''1882'''; Tucker was re-elected with 54.95% of the vote, defeating Readjuster [[Henry J. Rives]] and Republican Woodfin. *'''1884'''; Tucker was re-elected, but to [[Virginia's 10th congressional district]] ==Later legal and academic career== Tucker made an unsuccessful but legally influential argument on behalf of [[August Spies]] and the other [[Haymarket Riot]] defendants during their appeal to the [[Supreme Court of the United States|Supreme Court]]. Elected [[professor]] of [[Constitutional law]] at [[Washington and Lee University]] in 1888, Tucker was [[Dean (education)|Dean]] of the [[Washington and Lee University School of Law|School of Law]] from 1893 to 1897. Tucker served as president of The [[Virginia Bar Association]] in 1891-1892, and president of the [[American Bar Association]] in 1894. ==Death and legacy== John Randolph Tucker died in 1897 in [[Lexington, Virginia]] and is buried in the family plot at [[Mount Hebron Cemetery and Gatehouse|Mt. Hebron cemetery]] in Winchester. His widow would join him in 1916. One of his sons, [[Henry St. George Tucker, III]], would follow in his footsteps by becoming Dean of the Washington and Lee Law School, and later a U.S. Congressman representing Winchester (1922-1932). J.R.Tucker's two volume treatise, ''The Constitution of the United States'', appeared posthumously in 1899. His Lexington home, [[Blandome]] was listed on the [[National Register of Historic Places]] in 2002.{{NRISref|version=2010a}} ==Works== *[http://cdl.library.cornell.edu/cgi-bin/moa/moa-cgi?notisid=ABQ7578-0138-17 Race Progress in the United States, by J. R. Tucker, ''The North American review''. / Volume 138, Issue 327 (February, 1884) pp. 163-178] *[http://cdl.library.cornell.edu/cgi-bin/moa/moa-cgi?notisid=ABQ0722-0047-25 The History of the Federal Convention of 1787, and of its work, by J. Randolph Tucker, ''New Englander and Yale review'' / Volume 47, Issue 209 (August, 1887) pp. 97-147.] *[http://cdl.library.cornell.edu/cgi-bin/moa/moa-cgi?notisid=ABQ7578-0146-206 Virginia in the Supreme Court, by J. In '''''L. Taylor v AE Pim''''', an important case in the [[South African law of succession]], the deceased was a [[widow]] who hired a man, Pim, to assist with her business after her [[husband]] died. She subsequently began [[courting|dating]] the man; she also started developing severe [[alcoholism]]. In terms of her [[Will and testament|will]], Pim was to be the sole [[heir]] of her [[assets]].
Shortly before the deceased’s death, she and Pim were on [[vacation|holiday]] together. When the deceased fell ill, Pim refused to allow the hotel in which they were staying to call a doctor for her. Finally, they insisted it was their duty to call one, who duly arrived. Due to the doctor's late arrival, however, she died.
The [[court of law|court]] held that, although Pim had not caused her death, he had allowed the [[Testator|testatrix]] to lead an immoral life, and was the one who had encouraged her [[alcohol abuse]]; therefore, he was unworthy to inherit from her estate.
== See also == * [[Law of succession in South Africa]] * [[Law of persons in South Africa]]
== References == * ''L. Taylor v AE Pim'' 1903 NLR 484.

revision.text: {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2012}} [[File:Jesus College crest, Ship Street entrance.JPG|upright|thumb|The crest of Jesus College above the entrance on [[Ship Street, Oxford|Ship Street]]]] [[Jesus College, Oxford|Jesus College]] is one of the [[Colleges of the University of Oxford|constituent colleges]] of the [[University of Oxford]] in England. The college was founded in 1571 by [[Elizabeth I of England|Queen Elizabeth I]] at the request of [[Hugh Price (lawyer)|Hugh Price]], a Welsh clergyman, who was Treasurer of [[St David's Cathedral]] in [[Pembrokeshire]]. The college still has strong links with Wales, and about 15% of students are Welsh.{{cite web|url=http://www.jesus.ox.ac.uk/about/jesus-college-and-wales|title=Jesus College and Wales|publisher=Jesus College, Oxford|accessdate=6 September 2012}} There are 340 undergraduates and 190 students carrying out postgraduate studies.{{cite web|url=http://www.jesus.ox.ac.uk/about/welcome-to-jesus-college|title=Welcome to Jesus College|last=Krebs|first=Lord|authorlink=John Krebs, Baron Krebs|publisher=Jesus College, Oxford|accessdate=6 September 2012}} Women have been admitted since 1974, when the college was one of the first five men's colleges to become co-educational.{{cite web|url=http://www.jesus.ox.ac.uk/about/the-modern-day|title=Jesus College Oxford – The Modern Day|publisher=Jesus College, Oxford|accessdate=6 September 2012}} Old members of Jesus College are sometimes known as "Jesubites".{{cite journal|url=http://alumni.jesus.ox.ac.uk/TT2005%20newsletter.pdf|title=Jesubites go forth!|accessdate=28 March 2007|last=Orringe|first=Natalie|year=2005|issue=[[Trinity Term]]|format=PDF|journal=The Jesus College Newsletter|publisher=Jesus College, Oxford|pages= 2–3|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090326022803/http://alumni.jesus.ox.ac.uk/TT2005%20newsletter.pdf|archivedate=26 March 2009}} [[Harold Wilson]] studied at Jesus College from 1934 to 1937, and was later the [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom]] during two periods (from October 1964 to June 1970, and from March 1974 to April 1976). More than 30 other [[Members of Parliament#United Kingdom|Members of Parliament]] (MPs) have been educated at the college, from [[John Salusbury (poet)|Sir John Salusbury]] who was elected as MP for [[Denbighshire (UK Parliament constituency)|Denbighshire]] in 1601 to [[Theresa Villiers]] who was elected as MP for [[Chipping Barnet (UK Parliament constituency)|Chipping Barnet]] in 2005. [[Leoline Jenkins|Sir Leoline Jenkins]], who became a [[Oxbridge Fellow|Fellow]] and later the [[List of Principals and Fellows of Jesus College, Oxford|Principal of the college]], was [[Secretary of State for the Northern Department]] from 1680 to 1681 and [[Secretary of State for the Southern Department]] from 1681 to 1685. [[Sir William Williams, 1st Baronet, of Gray's Inn|Sir William Williams]] served as [[Speaker of the House of Commons (UK)|Speaker of the House of Commons]] from 1680 to 1685 and as [[Solicitor General for England and Wales]] from 1687 to 1689. [[H. E. A. Cotton|Evan Cotton]] was MP for [[Finsbury East (UK Parliament constituency)|Finsbury East]] before holding the position of President of the Bengal Legislative Council from 1922 to 1925. Several Welsh politicians have been educated at the college, some representing constituencies in Wales (such as [[John Wogan|Sir John Wogan]], representing [[Pembrokeshire (UK Parliament constituency)|Pembrokeshire]] at various times between 1614 and 1644) and others working outside Parliament, such as [[David John Williams|D. J. Williams]], a co-founder of the Welsh nationalist party [[Plaid Cymru]]. Other students at the college have subsequently held political offices in other countries. [[Norman Washington Manley]] was [[Prime Minister of Jamaica|Chief Minister]] of Jamaica from 1955 to 1962. [[P. T. Rajan]] was [[List of Chief Ministers of Tamil Nadu|Chief Minister of Madras Presidency]] between April and August 1936. [[Heather Wilson]] was the first Old Member of the college to sit in the [[United States House of Representatives]], where she represented [[New Mexico's 1st congressional district]] from 1998 to 2009. The Australian politician [[Neal Blewett]] was a member of the [[Australian House of Representatives]] from 1977 to 1994, a [[Government of Australia|Government Minister]] from 1983 to 1994 and [[High Commissioner]] to the UK from 1994 to 1998. [[Pixley ka Isaka Seme]], who studied for a BCL between 1906 and 1909, was one of the founder members of the [[African National Congress]]. Several prominent judges and lawyers were educated at the college. [[John Sankey, 1st Viscount Sankey|Viscount Sankey]], who was [[Lord Chancellor]] from 1929 to 1935, studied for a BA in History and BCL between 1885 and 1891. [[Herbert du Parcq, Baron du Parcq|Lord du Parcq]] was appointed as a [[Lord of Appeal in Ordinary]] in 1946. [[Richard Richards (MP)|Sir Richard Richards]] became [[Lord Chief Baron of the Exchequer]] in 1817. The Scottish MP and lawyer [[Ronald King Murray, Lord Murray|Lord Murray]] was appointed a [[Senator of the College of Justice]] in 1979. The solicitor [[David Lewis (Lord Mayor)|Sir David Lewis]] was [[Lord Mayor of the City of London]] from 2007 to 2008. Other lawyers who studied at the college include [[James Chadwin|James Chadwin QC]], who defended the [[Yorkshire Ripper]], and [[Arthur James (judge)|Sir Arthur James]], who prosecuted the [[Great Train Robbery (1963)|Great Train Robbers]] and later became a judge of the [[Court of Appeal of England and Wales|Court of Appeal]]. Academic lawyers include [[J Duncan M Derrett]], Professor of Oriental Laws in the [[University of London]] from 1965 to 1982, and [[Alfred Hazel]], [[Reader (academic rank)|Reader]] in English Law at [[All Souls College, Oxford]]. ==Alumni== ;Abbreviations used in the following tables: * M – Year of [[matriculation]] at Jesus College (a dash indicates that the individual did not matriculate at the college) * G – Year of [[graduation]] / conclusion of study at Jesus College (a dash indicates that the individual graduated from another college) * DNG – Did not graduate: left the college without taking a degree * ? – Year unknown; an approximate year is used for table-sorting purposes. * (F/P) after name – later became a [[Oxbridge Fellow|Fellow]] or Principal of Jesus College, and included on the [[list of Principals and Fellows of Jesus College, Oxford|list of Principals and Fellows]] * (HF) after name – later became an Honorary Fellow of Jesus College, and included on the [[List of Honorary Fellows of Jesus College, Oxford|list of Honorary Fellows]] ;Degree abbreviations * Undergraduate degree: BA – [[Bachelor of Arts]] * Postgraduate degrees: :* BCL – [[Bachelor of Civil Law]] :* MA – [[MA Oxon|Master of Arts]] :* MPhil – [[Master of Philosophy]] :* DCL – [[Doctor of Civil Law]] :* DPhil – [[Doctor of Philosophy]] The subject studied and the [[British undergraduate degree classification|degree classification]] are included, where known. Until the early 19th century, undergraduates read for a [[Bachelor of Arts]] degree that included study of Latin and Greek texts, mathematics, geometry, philosophy and theology. Individual subjects at undergraduate level were only introduced later: for example, Mathematics (1805), Natural Science (1850), [[Law degree|Jurisprudence]] (1851, although it had been available before this to students who obtained special permission), Modern History (1851) and Theology (1871). Geography and Modern Languages were introduced in the 20th century. Music had been available as a specialist subject before these changes; medicine was studied as a post-graduate subject.{{cite web|url=http://www.oxfordarchives.org.uk/frequently_asked_questions.htm#Q3|title=College Archives – FAQs|publisher=Oxford Archivists’ Consortium|accessdate=30 October 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090106020007/http://www.oxfordarchives.org.uk/frequently_asked_questions.htm#Q3|archivedate=6 January 2009|df=dmy-all}} {{dynamic list}} revision.text:
{{improverefs|date=January 2014}} The '''Local Government Act, 2001''' (No. 37 of 2001) was enacted by the [[Oireachtas]] of [[Ireland (state)|Ireland]] on 21 July 2001. Most of the provisions of the Act came into operation on 1 January 2002. The act was a restatement and amendment of previous legislation, which was centred on the [[Local Government (Ireland) Act 1898]]. The 2001 act remains in force, although significantly amended by the [[Local Government Reform Act 2014]].
According to the explanatory memorandum issued before the passing of the Act, its purposes were to: *enhance the role of the elected member, *support community involvement with local authorities in a more participative local democracy, *modernise local government legislation, and provide the framework for new financial management systems and other procedures to promote efficiency and effectiveness, *underpin generally the programme of local government renewal.
==Local government areas== The Act established local government areas based on those already created by previous legislation. The types of areas listed in the Act are:
'''Counties''': Identical to the administrative counties established by the [[Local Government (Ireland) Act 1898]] and modified by later legislation. The opportunity was taken to rename Tipperary (North Riding) and Tipperary (South Riding) as [[North Tipperary]] and [[South Tipperary]] respectively.
'''Cities''': These were the [[County borough]]s created by the [[Local Government (Ireland) Act 1898|1898 Act]] and later legislation, renamed. All the county boroughs except Galway had previously had the courtesy title of [[city]] by charter or letters patent.
'''Boroughs''': The five existing non-county boroughs continued in existence. In addition it was recognised that [[Kilkenny]] could continue to be called a city, in spite of being governed by a borough council and not being a former county borough.
'''Towns''': The remaining town authorities, formerly known as [[Urban district (Great Britain and Ireland)|urban district]]s or towns with [[Town Commissioners|town commissioners]], were all redesignated as towns.
==Local authorities== A council was established for each of the local government areas with the title [[county council]], city council, borough council, or [[Town Councils in the Republic of Ireland|town council]] (as appropriate).
==Membership of councils== One of the most controversial aspects of the Act was the abolition of the so-called "[[dual mandate]]". This meant that members of the [[Oireachtas]] ([[Dáil Éireann]] and [[Seanad Éireann]]) could no longer be candidates for local authority elections. This was taken out of the original act after protests from [[Fianna Fáil]] [[backbencher]]s who were also councillors.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.independent.ie/opinion/analysis/no-political-will-to-rock-the-cosy-boat-that-is-the-seanad-502066.html |title=No political will to rock the cosy boat that is the Seanad |last=Murphy |first=John A |date=14 July 2002|work=Sunday Independent |quote=The councillor lobby which stymied Noel Dempsey's plans to end the dual mandate |accessdate=16 April 2010|location=Dublin }}</ref> It was introduced in a 2003 amendment after a compensation package was agreed.<ref>{{cite book |chapterurl=http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/2003/en/act/pub/0017/print.html#sec2 |title=Local Government (No. 2) Act 2003 |date=June 2, 2003 |series=[[Irish Statute Book]] |chapter=§2 Amendment of Principal Act — insertion of new section 13A |accessdate=2009-10-06}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.independent.ie/national-news/news-in-brief-215369.html |title=Local government needs independent 'fiscal autonomy' |last=Geaney |first=Louise |date=2 June 2003 |work=Irish Independent |quote=The Local Government Bill 2000 proposed to abolish the dual mandate but the Act dropped the idea, only for it to be re-introduced — with a handy €12,800 sweetener — in 2003. |accessdate=16 April 2010 |location=Dublin }}</ref>
===Directly-elected mayors=== Inspired by the office of [[Mayor of London]] created in 2000, Chapter 3 of Part 5 of the 2001 act as passed provided for a [[Direct election|directly-elected]] chairperson (mayor or ''cathaoirleach'') of each county and city council. This was to take effect from the [[Irish local elections, 2004|2004 local elections]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://oireachtasdebates.oireachtas.ie/debates%20authoring/debateswebpack.nsf/takes/seanad2001071000007#N24|title=Local Government Bill, 2000: Second Stage|last=Wallace|first=Danny|date=10 July 2001|work=Seanad Éireann debates|publisher=Oireachtas|pages=Vol.167 No.14 p.7 c.1339 |nopp=Y |quote=From 2004, the cathaoirleach of counties and cities will be elected by direct vote of the people and will hold office for the life of the council.|accessdate=12 October 2016}}</ref> However, a 2003 amendment repealed the provision before it was implemented.<ref>{{cite web|last=Cullen|first=Martin| url=http://oireachtasdebates.oireachtas.ie/debates%20authoring/debateswebpack.nsf/takes/seanad2003022600007#N11|title=Local Government Bill 2003: Second Stage|date=26 February 2003|work=Seanad Éireann debates|publisher=Oireachtas|pages=Vol.171 No.12 p.7 c.937 |nopp=Y |quote=the Bill repeals legislative provisions currently in place which provide for the introduction of direct election of cathaoirligh of county–city councils in 2004. The Bill provides, therefore, that in 2004 the cathaoirleach will be chosen by the newly elected councillors from among their number as in the past.|accessdate=12 October 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/eli/2003/act/17/section/7/enacted/en/html|title=Local Government (No. 2) Act 2003, Section 7|work=[[Irish Statute Book]]|accessdate=12 October 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.broadsheet.ie/2016/07/04/a-dublin-mayor-nightmare/|title=The Dublin Mayor Nightmare|last=Mooney|first=Derek|work=Broadsheet.ie|publisher=[[John Ryan (publisher)|John Ryan]]|accessdate=12 October 2016}}</ref>
==Local Government Commission== Part 11 of the Act mandated the establishment of a permanent Local Government Commission to propose changes to local authority areas, local electoral areas, or local authority powers. This part never came into force and was repealed by the 2014 act.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/eli/isbc/2001_37.html|title=Local Government Act 2001: Amendments, Commencement, SIs made under the Act|date=20 September 2016|work=[[Irish Statute Book]]|accessdate=13 October 2016}}</ref> The previous practice of ad-hoc committees for boundary reviews continued after 2001 and was formalised by the 2014 act.
==References== ===Sources=== * {{cite web |url=http://www.oireachtas.ie/viewdoc.asp?fn=/documents/bills28/bills/2000/2300/default.htm |title=Local Government Bill, 2000 |work=Legislative Observatory: Bills 1992–2014 |publisher=Oireachtas |accessdate=22 January 2014}} * {{cite web |url=http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/eli/2001/act/37/enacted/en/print |title=Local Government Act, 2001 (as enacted)|date=21 July 2001 |work=[[Irish Statute Book]]|accessdate=11 October 2016 }} * {{cite web |url=http://www.lawreform.ie/_fileupload/RevisedActs/WithAnnotations/EN_ACT_2001_0037.PDF |format=PDF |publisher=[[Law Reform Commission (Ireland)|Law Reform Commission]] |title=Local Government Act 2001 (as amended to 1 January 2016) |work=Revised Acts with Annotations |date=2016 |accessdate=11 October 2016 }} ===Citations=== {{reflist}}

page.title: Misclassification of employees as independent contractors

revision.text:
{{Globalize/US|date=August 2017}} {{UStaxation}} '''Misclassification of employees as independent contractors''' in the [[United States]] can occur with respect to tax treatment or the [[Fair Labor Standards Act]].
The U.S. [[Government Accountability Office]] (GAO) reports that the IRS claims to lose millions of dollars in uncollected payroll, [[Social Security (United States)|social security]], [[Medicare (United States)|Medicare]] and unemployment insurance taxes because of misclassification of independent contractors by taxpayers.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.gao.gov/archive/1996/gg96130t.pdf|title=Issues in Classifying Workers as Employees or Independent Contractors: Testimony Before the Subcommittee on Oversight Committee on Ways and Means|last=Gandhi|first=Natwar M.|date=1996-06-20|website=[[United States General Accounting Office]]|format=PDF|access-date=}}</ref>
According to [[Internal Revenue Service]] (IRS) [[Commissioner of Internal Revenue|Commissioner]] [[Mark W. Everson]] in a statement made November 3, 2005, IRS audits of small businesses organized as corporations increased from 7,294 in 2004 to 17,867 in 2005. [https://www.irs.gov/newsroom/article/0,,id=150358,00.html]
==Taxation== Employers must report the incomes of employees and independent contractors using the IRS forms [[Form W-2|W-2]] and [[Form 1099-MISC|1099]], respectively. Employers pay various [[tax]]es (i.e. [[Social Security (United States)|Social Security]] and [[Medicare (United States)|Medicare]] taxes, [[Federal Unemployment Tax Act|unemployment tax]]es, etc.) on the wages of a worker that is classified as an employee. These taxes are generally not paid by the employer on the compensation of a worker classified as an independent contractor. Instead, the contractor is responsible for their employer's share of the taxes when he or she pays self-employment taxes at the end of the year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.texasovertimeattorney.com/blog/withholding-for-payroll-taxes-and-misclassifying-workers-as-independent-contractors-why-this-ca.cfm|title=Withholding for Payroll Taxes & Misclassifying Workers as Independent Contractors: Why This Can Hurt You at Tax Time.|publisher=}}</ref>
Classification affects whether a worker can receive unemployment benefits. In many states, independent contractors are not eligible for unemployment benefits because nothing has been paid into the unemployment insurance fund on their behalf. Employers who have no employees are not required to make payments to the unemployment insurance fund (since there is no one to claim benefits).
Workers classified as independent contractors whose contract is terminated can contact their state unemployment agency (for example [[Employment Development Department]] (EDD) in California) and file a claim for unemployment. EDD investigates and determines whether the worker was misclassified, and potentially award unemployment benefits. According to state-level studies, 10% to 20% of employers misclassify at least one worker as an independent contractor.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.epi.org/publication/independent-contractor-misclassification/|title=(In)dependent Contractor Misclassification|work=Economic Policy Institute|access-date=2017-11-06|language=en-US}}</ref>
==Reclassification== IRS reclassification as an employee occurs where persons claimed as (or claiming to be) [[independent contractors]] are recategorized by the [[Internal Revenue Service]] (IRS), or by state tax authorities, as [[Form W-2|W-2]] [[employee]]s. The reclassification can result in the imposition of substantial fines, penalties and back-taxes for which the [[employer]] is generally liable.
==Employee vs. independent contractor== IRS regulations state that a worker is an employee if the employer can control what is to be done and how it is to be done. This was codified in revenue ruling 87-41, and is generally called "the twenty factor test".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-pdf/p15a.pdf|title=Publication 15-A: Employer's Supplemental Tax Guide (for use in 2017)|last=|first=|date=2017-01-05|website=|publisher=Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.irs.gov/businesses/small-businesses-self-employed/independent-contractor-self-employed-or-employee|title=Independent Contractor (Self-Employed) or Employee?|website=www.irs.gov|language=en-us|access-date=2017-04-09}}</ref> By contrast, if the worker controls the means and method of achieving the required results, leaving the employer with the right only to define the desired result, they are correctly classified as an independent contractor.
Employees and independent contractors have very different benefits. Employees are entitled to the protection of wage and hour laws and are protected from discrimination and retaliation by employers. Employees may be legally entitled to family medical leave and benefits such as medical insurance and pension plans. Employees are entitled to bargain collectively with their employers. Employees are entitled to workers' compensation for job-related injuries and employers must pay into social security, Medicare, and unemployment insurance for their employees.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.irs.gov/businesses/small-businesses-self-employed/employee-benefits|title=Employee Benefits|website=www.irs.gov|language=en-us|access-date=2017-04-09}}</ref> No benefits or employer tax payments are available to contractors, who must pay for their own benefits and unemployment taxes.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/08/17/technology/in-the-sharing-economy-workers-find-both-freedom-and-uncertainty.html|title=In the Sharing Economy, Workers Find Both Freedom and Uncertainty|last=Singer|first=Natasha|date=2014-08-16|work=The New York Times|access-date=2017-04-09|issn=0362-4331}}</ref>
Service sector employees are more likely than others to be misclassified as independent contractors. Commonly misclassified positions include delivery and taxi drivers, nurses and home health aides, housekeepers<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.rhdtlaw.com/1099d-employer-liability-independent-contractors-service-sector/|title=Independent Contractors or Employees? Who Gets a 1099?|date=2014-10-08|work=Rukin Hyland|access-date=2017-04-09|language=en-US}}</ref> and adult entertainment workers.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/are-exotic-dancers-employees-or-independent-contractors-1417570961|title=Are Exotic Dancers Employees or Independent Contractors?|last=O'Brien|first=Rebecca Davis|date=2014-12-03|work=Wall Street Journal|access-date=2017-04-09|issn=0099-9660}}</ref>
Efforts by firms in the [[sharing economy]] such as [[Uber (company)|Uber]] to maintain independent contractor status for "partners" such as Uber drivers have been questioned.<ref name="Medium42015">{{cite news|url=https://medium.com/matter/what-strippers-can-teach-uber-1f5b15e5b427|title=What Strippers Can Teach Uber|date=April 20, 2015|issue=Medium.com|quote=Many of these companies are built with workers who are not even considered workers at all. In a twist of business logic that drives much of the sharing economy, these delivery people, drivers, and maids aren't employees – they're entrepreneurs.|author1=Lauren Smiley|accessdate=April 21, 2015}}</ref>
IRS Form SS-8 can be filed with the IRS to request that the agency determine the classification of a worker.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/business/technology/sd-fi-labor-blurred-lines-20170807-story.html|title=Who are you, gig worker or employee?|last=Rafter|first=Michelle|date=October 3, 2017|website=|language=en|accessdate=November 13, 2017}}</ref>
==Fair Labor Standards Act== In July 2015, the [[U.S. Department of Labor]] issued new guidelines on worker classification. "A worker who is economically dependent on an employer is suffered or permitted to work by the employer. Thus, applying the economic realities test in view of the expansive definition of "employ" under the Act, most workers are employees under the [[Fair Labor Standards Act]]."<ref name=Weil>{{cite web |url = http://www.dol.gov/whd/workers/Misclassification/AI-2015_1.pdf |publisher = United States Department of Labor |title = The Application of the Fair Labor Standards Act's "Suffer or Permit" Standard in the Identification of Employees Who Are Misclassified as Independent Contractors |author = Weil, David |date = July 15, 2015 |accessdate = July 15, 2015 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150716032022/http://www.dol.gov/whd/workers/Misclassification/AI-2015_1.pdf |archivedate = July 16, 2015 |df = }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/labor-department-releases-guidance-on-classification-of-workers-1436954401 | publisher=Wall Street Journal | date=July 15, 2015 | accessdate=July 15, 2015| title=Employees vs. Independent Contractors: U.S. Weighs In on Debate Over How to Classify Workers | author=Trottman, Melanie}}</ref>
{{quote|...the economic realities of the relationship, and not the label an employer gives it, are determinative. Thus, an agreement between an employer and a worker designating or labeling the worker as an independent contractor is not indicative of the economic realities of the working relationship and is not relevant to the analysis of the worker's status.<ref name = Weil />}}
==See also== * Similar questions in UK: [[IR35]]

Freeman, ''The Tax Adviser'', February 1 1996] *[http://newstandardnews.net/content/index.cfm/items/3428 "FedEx Drivers Fight for ‘Employee’ Status, Rights", Megan Tady, ''The NewStandard'', July 18, 2006] *[http://www.infozine.com/news/stories/op/storiesView/sid/16328/ "Sebelius Announces Campaign to Ensure Fairness for Kansas Workers and Businesses", ''infozine.com'', July 11, 2006] *[http://www.cnn.com/2007/POLITICS/10/23/congress.blackwater/index.html "Waxman: Blackwater may have evaded millions in taxes", Justine Redman, ''CNN'', October 23, 2007] *[https://www.nytimes.com/2014/08/17/technology/in-the-sharing-economy-workers-find-both-freedom-and-uncertainty.html? "In the Sharing Economy, Workers Find Both Freedom and Uncertainty", Natasha Singer, ''New York Magazine'', August 16, 2014] *[http://www.rhdtlaw.com/1099d-employer-liability-independent-contractors-service-sector/ "I was 1099’d: Employer Liability for Independent Contractors in the Service Sector", Melinda Pilling, ''Rukin, Hyland, Doria & Tindall'', October 8]
